_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Hercules LLC is committed to the pursuit of zero harm to our employees and customers, zero incidents, and zero impact to the environment.  We work to:



-Provide a safe and healthful environment for employees, customers, and communities.

-Comply with laws, regulations, and corporate guidelines that apply to safety, health, the environment, and product quality.

-Drive continuous improvement by using management systems to meet goals and measure performance.

-Foster positive reinforcement to improve and reward employee behavior, systems, and performance.

-Invest in products and processes to maximize safety, health and environmental values, and to minimize adverse consequences.



By these actions, we ensure our contribution to the growth of our corporate shareholder value.



We will define strategic objectives, develop tactical plans, identify clear accountability, provide necessary resources, and measure our progress on safety, health, and environmental matters on an ongoing basis. Our planning will consider business goals and significant safety, health, and environmental aspects of our products and operations.



We will evaluate the safety, health, and environmental impacts of new and existing products and operations and will work to reduce the adverse impacts.



We will provide for an open dialogue on safety, health, and environmental issues relating to our products and operations with our stakeholders, including shareholders, employees, customers, suppliers, government agencies, and communities.



We will work to continually reduce workplace injuries; incidents with the potential for causing property damage, material loss, or interruption of our business; waste; and releases to the environment.



We emphasize product stewardship and advocate its importance to our suppliers, distributors, and customers.



Every Hopewell employee has a role to play.  All of us are responsible and accountable for adhering to the letter and spirit of this policy. All of us m

ust incorporate safety, health, and environmental considerations into our daily business activities. 



FACILITY DESCRIPTION



The Hopewell Plant is located on 390 acres in the City of Hopewell. The facility produces cellulose derivatives that are used as thickeners in soups, gravies, pancake syrups, and toothpaste. In the construction industry these derivatives are used as thickeners for latex paints, oil drilling compounds, joint cements, and caulking. These products are also used in pharmaceuticals, inks, and the production of paper.  In the manufacture of these derivatives, RMP-covered toxic chemicals (ethylene oxide, and propylene oxide) are used as raw materials.  By treating cellulose from trees or cotton with caustic and reacting the resulting intermediate with various chemicals, we manufacture cellulose derivatives.

The facility maintains multiple product certifications for manufacturing practices and product quality. These certifications are maintained through customer and third party audits which ensure the continued integrity of our processes and products as demanded by our customers.

 

ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



All production processes using the RMP-covered toxic and flammable chemicals on the Hopewell Plant are covered by the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard. The plant has a comprehensive process safety management system in place. Operators are thoroughly trained about their jobs and have written operating procedures readily available via site intranet.  Operators perform observations of their equipment as frequently as hourly and at least every eight hours. Equipment is subject to the mechanical integrity program which requires inspection and testing of critical equipment sometimes as frequently as weekly and at least as required by standards, manufacturer recommendations, good engineering practice, etc. Mechanics are also thoroughly trained on their job skills and equipment inspection procedures. Each process is subject to process ha

zards analysis at least every five years to continually improve the safety and reduce the chance for fires, releases and spills in the operation. Management of change requires that a team approve changes to processes and equipment. Most processes are computer-controlled using a distributed control system (DCS) and all are monitored continuously by operators to prevent hazardous conditions from developing.  Processes also have failsafe devices that shut down equipment before hazardous releases can occur. Automatic leak detection devices are present to notify operators to take preventative actions in the event of a leak in the storage, unloading, and use areas of covered chemicals. Periodic audits to identify potentials for fire, release, or other hazards are performed by plant and corporate personnel. 



FIVE YEAR HISTORY



In the past five years, the Hopewell Plant has not experienced an accidental release of ethylene oxide, propylene oxide, ethyl chloride or ethyl ether that had any effect to either onsite or offsite locations. No employee was injured during this time period as a result of a release of any regulated chemicals. This is a result of the prevention program described above and training that all employees receive on how to do their jobs safely. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Hopewell Plant has a written emergency response plan. This plan is coordinated with the City of Hopewell's emergency plan. The plan describes the actions employees will take in response to an emergency such as accidental chemical release, fire or explosion, or a medical emergency. All employees are trained to "first responder" level which means that they know what to do if they discover an emergency situation. A first responder will notify appropriate plant personnel of the emergency. This notification could be by telephone or via two-way radio as most shift team members carry a radio. The plant siren would be activated to notify everyone on plant of the emergency. The Plant

Emergency Response Team is trained to handle chemical releases, incipient fires, or medical emergencies. The team is equipped with an ambulance, and a hazardous materials trailer stocked with materials for responding to and stopping chemical releases. Also available are the Hopewell Fire and Police Departments along with mutual aid agreements with neighboring industries if additional resources are needed. Note that plant personnel drill at least annually with local public safety personnel. 

 

Communications with the City can be via radio, dialing 911 on telephone, or the Hopewell Emergency Notification System (HENS).  HENS is a local radio network connected to local industries, public safety personnel, nearby schools and the community center providing immediate notification of an emergency.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Continuous training on operational and emergency procedures and installation of additional alarms, lighting and upgrades to process controls will improve the safety of our processes and our overall safety management program.
